Pros:
- Music is good.
Cons:
- Everything else.

I really liked the idea this game was going for. What I found was probably one of the most credible successors for Big Rigs. There is no car damage, you can pop off some lamp posts and that's it. Only things happening when you crash are either flying around, spinning or knocking back like crazy with no real penalty. Calling controls arcade-like would be extremely generous, but they are just stiff and cars don't really turn around like you want to. Music is kinda good but most of the time its so upbeat it only adds to comedy value of the game.

There are three main modes to speak of. Time trial is what it is, if you are masochistic enough to master controls of this game. Race mode has some CPU opponents you can push around like they have zero weight. There is no multiplayer. Lastly there is free roam where you can explore the map which takes 10 minutes tops, run through pedestrians and use handful cars available to you. There's many kinds of cars parked but you can't use most of them. You also have a jump that doesn't seem to have any purpose other than fooling you to think you can get over some fences and stuff. Nope. Most fun thing I found was driving on the ocean floor. Yeah.

It is sad to see some effort definitely went into this. All in vain. Also worth mentioning is that the engine is very heavy considering what the game looks like. You can tweak it up a little since its straight up Unreal 3. Or should I say you can try. I even ran out of video memory which is legendary. I didn't find a way to rebind controls. I tried because I didn't like the preset.

To sum it all up: don't buy this game if you want a good racing game. If you want to cry or laugh, I think you should actually buy this! It is very cheap and can make you laugh if you are one of those into bad games. Definitely has also educational value for game developers everywhere.

reviewText:
Ocean City Racing is an indie racing game, made in the UT3 engine.

The game feels and plays like an old arcade race game made by SEGA. Whenever you crash into other cars or buildings you car stays intact. You could destroy things like small fences but whenever you ride into a pedestrian your car just stops. I know this is no carmageddon but perhaps there should not have been npc's in a game like this. The cars also have some unnatural physics. It would have been nice if you could play the game with a controller but mine did not seem to work.

There are 3 game modes: Time-Trial, Race Mode and Free Roam. Obviously, Time-Trial is to beat your own times, Race-Mode is just racing opponents and Free-roam is driving around an 'open world' city.

The graphics are not that special these days but they are not that bad. The city looks OK but I doubt anyone plays this game for sight-seeing.
Although not my taste, the music is pretty good however, totally not suited for a race game, in my opinion.

Without any achievements, online leaderboards or online/offline multiplayer, the game will most likely bore you after max 1 hour. Even though the game is cheap, I still can't recommend this one.

reviewText:
Oh boy. I just keep finding ways to get impressed. At a retail price of $3, Ocean City Racing (well, OCEAN CITY RACING, but I think you'll forgive me if drop the caps) is a pretty cheap buy, but as a lover of racing games I'll give almost anything a try. It doesn't always go well, like Redneck Racing or Motorama, and Ocean City Racing is stacking up to be another mistake languishing in my library.

The game already fails on a technical level with a barebones options menu, offering an extremely limited resolution choiceâ€”not even offering my native resolution of 1600x900, the third most common resolution by Steam's hardware surveyâ€”no graphics options, no volume sliders, no rebindable controls...it's just a mess. And the game runs terribly and looks worse, with a massively overdone motion blur to boot that makes it more or less impossible to see what you're doing. Of course, as mentioned, there is no way to turn this off. Additionally, all the button prompts given are for keyboard controls, so anyone who wants to play with a controller will find themselves randomly pressing buttons to try to figure things out if they didn't memorize the controls from the options menu.

The car handling is utter garbage. You have very little control and will find yourself bumping off walls left and right. Conveniently there's a reset car button that doesn't seem to have much penalty, so I think this was expected. The handbrake button has been replaced by a spin out button, leading to further resets. The boost fails to give any real feeling of speed, but nonetheless makes the car all the more likely to go out of control in corners, adding yet more usefulness to the reset button unless you save it for straights. And of course there's the random physics bugs where a tap against a wall can send you flying into the air. And despite all this bumping around and lost time, the computers have it even worse; I watched them crash on their own all over the place. They don't know how to play this game any better than I do! I had an atrocious time but still somehow came in second in my first race.

So, after the disaster of a race, I decided I would try free roam mode. You walk around in a first-person camera and can't interact with anything but the cars. You drive around a little more freely which leads to a little bit less bumping around, but the driving still feels terrible, the game still looks like someone dumped Vaseline on it, you still randomly get launched into the air, and there doesn't seem to really be any point to doing any of this.

It was at this point I realized I had about all I could take of this game and decided to try collecting my thoughts together into words. That really is all there is to it: nothing in this game inspires me to play it, and on both technical and design fronts it actively discourages me from playing. There was not one moment when playing this game that I thought to myself I had fun

reviewText:
First off, do I recommend this game? It's hard to say. I want to give the game a good review for the effort put in, so this is the best I can do.

I'll try to keep the review as quick and concise as possible, so read on :)

While the game has a good concept, the actual result needs some work. I like how it is open world, and it has what I wish a lot of open world car games would include - a first person mode, where you can walk around, explore, and hop into other cars you see.

I know GTA allows you to do this, but I don't like the extreme violence in that series, and therefore don't play em.

Physics wise, the cars behave fine at low speeds but once they are moving, I feel that they are not loose enough on the rear wheels, and thus feel a bit weird (i.e, they don't slide out at the back if cornering hard).

The game uses the Unreal engine, so the graphical effects are quite nice. However, the quality of the car modles, and overall world detail could use some work. I understand that only a few people made the game, so it's not always possible to go into heavy detail like AAA games have, but still, they could have delayed its release and worked on the models a bit more.

I noticed some graphical shadow bugs when running fullscreen - not sure what was causing that. My computer definitely isn't underpowered, so it's most likely some bug.


Content-wise, what you get is appropriate for the price (I think there are around 10 cars). For the most part, I noticed a dfferent suspension setup values for each car. For example, the Camaro looks and feels different to the Mini.

The world, in my opinion, needs some more stuff to do though. After half an hour of driving, I found myself wanting to either challenge someone or upgrade my car. I know there is a race mode, but in any game, I much rather race real people than AI.


All up, I appreciate the work put into the game, but I honestly have to say that I won't play the game much, because there is nothing to bring me back to it later - which, in my case, is multiplayer.

It doesn't matter what game I'm playing - if it's single player (especially in the racing genre), sooner or later I'm going to get bored of it. Good example: the very first GRID game in Codemaster's series had multiplayer support pulled - and I haven't played that game in a good 5 (or how many years since the servers were shut down, I can't remember) years since driving against AI is so... boring.



Final Conclusion:

If you have a few bucks to spend, and some time to kill, then maybe you will like it. Like they say, it's the price of a cup of coffee (although I never drink the stuff :P). If you're looking for a multiplayer game with a huge world, high quality models, and lots of content, then no.

As a side note, young kids will probably enjoy the violence-free open world and ability to walk to and drive different cars.

The game certainly needs more work to be a polished and fun experience.

reviewText:
This game is actually fun. Try the racing mode. Once you get the hang of it it's very enjoyable to the extent of being therapeutical. The physics adds a lot to the enjoyment. It's so easy to spin the AI cars around by ramming into them, and they ram into you as well. It is actually quite funny.

That being said, it's a casual racer with pretty graphics by the Unreal Engine 3. Getting first place shouldn't be too difficult if you actually try to win.

The free roam mode adds some quality mindless exploration.

Some other reviews say this game is great for kids, and I agree. But that doesn't mean it's meant only for them.
People tend to expect too much from games it seems.

Unique physics, unreal graphics and good opponent AI, what more could you ask for?

The soundtrack is actually quite relaxing, and a change from the usual stuff I listen to.

Overall this game is a good escape. Something we could all use every now and then.

reviewText:
Ok so this game isn't bad, but its not particularly good either.

Firstly, the game looks superb. the models are pretty, the map looks good and the lighting is nice.
The free roam option in this is fun, it makes the game basically a new version of midtown madness! It would be great if the racing option was fused with the freeroam, this would make the game a bit more fun.
The cars handle great, that is untill you crash.

The braking feels almost like it doesnt work properally and the replay function is incredibly buggy in the racing section - at times it placed be somewhere completely random, making me lose.

If this was to be fixed, and well... finished it could be good, this has the potential to be a great game!
I can't really complain too much for how much it is worth, it can be fun if you have nothing better to do.
I bought this in a 50c bundle with lots of other games so I guess I got my moneys worth.

The cars handle like bricks; actually, that's an insult to a brick. I've played some pretty tough racing games; but the handing of these cars is abymsal.

Despite having a system that meets requirements; I found the gameplay freezing up for a second or two on a very regular basis.

I think both TDU and Burnout Paradise have larger worlds.

If they go ahead and add more resolutions rather than using a fixed few; I could *maybe* recommend this game; otherwise, save your money.

Wasn't very impressed and was just disappointed that a game with so much potential feel short of even getting off the starting line.

reviewText:
I noticed this game in my backlog and figured I'd give it a go. I love driving aimlessly in an open world! So I start it up and it sorta chugs through the loading screen, on this rather powerful gaming PC. So I check the graphics options and... there's really just resolution. Now, I've used the Unreal Engine before, there are PLENTY of options built in that could be easily listed there, but okay, I turn down the resolution and try the free roaming.

I start on-foot, walking to the nearest car. Quite slowly, but a neat touch, at least, and I can jump slightly. Get in, start driving around. Hit a pedestrian, and... they stand stock-still while my car thuds to a stop like it hit a brick wall. Okay, then. Drive away, go to head to the bridge in the distance. Try to drift, brakes make steering no longer a thing. Okay, then. Try to drift with the e-brake, practically instant stop. Okay, then. Bump into the car in front of me and it cartoonishly soars over my hood. That's pretty neat, actually! Probably not right, but very entertaining. Hit the next car, thud to a stop. Bump into a guard rail, thud to a stop. Hit some chairs, they go flying, hit the table the chairs were at, thud to a stop. So that's weirdly inconsistent, but okay, don't hit things. Got a bit lost trying to get up to the bridge, finally find a looping ramp up to it, get on, drive over and head to a small island. I can see another city in the distance... but driving to there magically pops in construction barriers. Oh, okay, I guess this game is in Early Access and they're still making the map! That explains a lot of the rough edges, that's fine.

I go back and drive around a bit, this time on an ATV, and awkwardly teeter around on it, my driver bizarrely superglued to the handlebars. Still neat to be able to drive around the smaller alleyways and such. I get off of it and walk into a subway station, fully modeled with a rather plainly textured train going by and posters of odd, stretched resolutions. Eh, that's all fine for Early Access, they'll fix it.

And then came the real bad part. It's NOT in Early Access. It's done"
